From: "nano_biquts" <jonh@polter.net>
X-Originating-IP: 130.207.140.184
Subject: Re: Materials potential list
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=22685443
X-Yahoo-Profile: nano_biquts

> I saw in the files a list of the potential possible essence levels 
> for all the materials.  So, I ask, how exactly does on get such 
> ridiculously high essence levels as 13s, 14s, and 15s for Altena 
> Alloy?

Its not easy. Most high level recipes revolve around getting 
dryad/aura to 15/14 as soon as possible then leeching energy as you 
slosh it back and forth with mirror pieces. For better materials that 
is just a matter of draining a 12 from the lower essences. But since 
AA is highly resistant to everything you can only directly get a 10 
on the lower essences. So usually a three pronged approach is needed 
were energy is passed between dryad/aura/sala gaining a level each 
cycle.
I have AsianGrinch's recipe for it somewhere, but I haven't posted it 
because its not worth doing. (I posted the maia lead recipe because 
noone would believe me otherwise)
Diorwood or Dragonscale are better choices for high level tempering.

GC | Sh He Fo Te | St Sl Pi MD | Wi Sh Dr Au Sa Gn Ji Un
--------------------------------------------------------
20 | 62 46 93 99 | 62 31 93 62 |  8  8  8  8  8  8  8  8 | Adamantite
10 | 50 30 70 20 | 80 25 35 45 |  7  8  5  9 10  7  7  7 | DiorWood

only 4 more essence resistance points than DiorWood.  Or is it just

become essentially meaningless?  And in that case, wouldn't that 
Aeriolite recipe with the some 116 total essence points end up being 
the best material to use?

To: LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com

User-Agent: eGroups-EW/0.82

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Length: 1017
X-Mailer: Yahoo Groups Message Poster
X-eGroups-Remote-IP: 66.218.66.88
From: ekm3777 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
Reply-To: no_reply@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: Materials potential list
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=101367387; email=no
X-Yahoo-Profile: ekm3777

GC means Growth Control

Long story short, it determines how effective the mana levels on a 
weapon will raise its attack power.

Example

If you have a Diorwood Weapon (Growth Control 10) with a base attack 
power of 50.  Now add 10 levels of Essence to the weapon and the 
attack power will be 100.  Another 10 levels of Essence (total 20) 
and the attack power will be 150, another 10 levels... 200 attack 
power.

In Adamantites case, the growth control is 20.  Weapon with 50 
attack power, you would have to add 20 levels of essences just to 
get it to 100 attack power, another 20 to get it 150, and another 20 
to reach 200 attack power.

The exact formula used is

(Total Essences + Growth Control) / Growth Control)

So if we take a Dragonscale weapon with 42 Total Essences

(42 + 14) / 14 = 3

The base attack power will get multiplied by 3.

Its the Growth Control which makes certain materials like AltenaFelt 
so powerful when you raise their Essence Levels.

Bottom Line:

Higher Growth Control = Bad

From: "nano_biquts" <jonh@polter.net>
X-Originating-IP: 130.207.140.184
Subject: Re: you guys are crazy!
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=22685443
X-Yahoo-Profile: nano_biquts

> wow, I have had this game forever, and I never knew that the weapon 
> making system was so deep.

Yah, its deep. But most of the work is done by a small number of 
items. (coins, sulpher/mercury, chaos/glow crystals) So once you 
understand those you can do quite a lot.

1. low level tempering
-glow recipes: these use the large amounts of energy available from 
glow crystals to get to 6s
-"quick" recipes: these use wizard cards (from mercury/sulpher) to 
lower resistances so its easy to get to 7/5s

2. mid level tempering
: this combines the above two ideas to get to 9s

3. high level tempering
: adds in consumptions to get 12s

4. ultra high level tempering
: multistep consumptions to get to 15s. more exotic items like mirror 
pieces are needed at this point

Subject: Re: [LoM Kitchen] Where to find mirror pieces?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=122563818
X-Yahoo-Profile: sinistar23

--0-263087821-1088717310=:71218
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Look through a walkthru and search for instances of "mirror piece", I think you can get 3 or 4 each run through the game.  Then you can "recycle" your mirror pieces (and other tempering materials) if you use the Prof. Bomb exploit:
 
You need an alternate save game file with a different name.  In that quest, you need to have found Prof. Bomb so that you can use weapons from other game files.  
 
Once that's ready, go back to your main game, and begin tempering your weapon.  SAVE before you start tempering mirror pieces, then when you've tempered your last mirror piece, save your game in a NEW SLOT, and go to Prof. Bomb & sell him the weapon you tempered the mirror pieces into.  Now, load up the alternate game file, go to Prof. Bomb, and buy the weapon that he's holding from your main file.  Now the weapon is linked to the alternate file.  Sell it back to the Prof.
 
Now load up your main game, using the slot that you saved at BEFORE spending your mirror pieces.  Go to Prof. Bomb, and buy the weapon that he's holding from the alternate file.  Now you have your weapon back in your main game.  The weapon has mirror pieces in it, but you've loaded your game at a point before you tempered the pieces - so you will still have them, as well as anything else you used in that period!
 
Repeat the trick as many times as you need to.  It's time consuming and expensive, but it still beats going through the game several times to collect all those pieces.

Subject: Re: Where to find mirror pieces?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188

If you're still interested in knowing where the four Mirror Pieces 
are:
1) The Birdcage Lighthouse, Madora Beach
2) The Underworld, further down than you go during "The Fallen 
Emperor"
3) The Bejewelled City, in one of the gem rooms
4) The Mana Tree, Sanctuary of Mana


From Trigger9898@hotmail.com Fri Jul 02 05:48:08 2004

> ok, two things... first, for the AdamPendant in the recipe book, 
> about half way down where it says "card-item" does it mean any item 
> that will add a card, and are there any that you definitely should 
> NOT put there?

In that case anything should work. Using a pixie might cost you a few 
extra dragonbloods at the end. But it will get pushed off because 
ragnarok will turn it into an EGC. World cards wouldn't be a problem 
because they'll go away when the wicked eyes are added. Sac nymph and 
NoD wouldn't cause problems there. And neither would holy 
water/garlicrown. Those are the only ones I can think of that might 
be a problem.


> second, anyone have any good recipes for a mantle, 
> besides in armor.txt? (thats right, i want a cape)

What are you looking for, something simpler?

special diet or anything.  I never saw it summon

to be sure, I recommend feeding it produce that will
quickly get its skill and magic up to 99, also you may
have to get his level up to 90+, make sure you have
the forbidden ring in order to level him up quickly.

Nothing but scare tactics as far as I'm concerned. 
They can't do anything to you for using p2p file
sharing.  Think about how much money it would cost
them just to sue one kid who doesn't even have the
money to pay them (nor do his parents).  It would be a
waste.  Their whole scheme is to make money.  

You've probably seen alot of the recent "big brother
is watching you" style advetisements around on
websites.  All their doing is trying to scare people
into not using p2p filesharing, or particularly,
downloading content that belongs to them.

Neither the RIAA or the MPAA have any connection with
the LoM OST so there's no way you can get in any
trouble for grabbing it again off kazaa (or whatever
you feel like using).

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [LoM Kitchen] re[6]:
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc


Sometimes spammers get ahold of our group email.  If it becomes a 
persistant problem, I set the group to Members Only, preventing them 
from mailing in, which causes their mail to bounce (so they stop 
sending it).

I would advise against replying to any spam.

Also, if you feel spam may be a problem, you can set "No Mail 
Messages" in your settings for the group, and simply check the group 
page for new messages.

I have deleted the spam messages, and I'll see if I'll need to 
temporarily Members-Only the group. :)

Sincerely,
JC "Myst Erik Ery" D

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc


The main reason I keep this open to the public is simply because some=20
people who do not have Yahoo accounts may have questions to ask.

However, if I hear more people who agree with you in that it should=20
be Members-Only for posting, I can keep it this way.

It doesn't guarantee protection from spam, but it does mean that I=20
can simply ban any spammer from the group, effectively preventing=20
spam from its source instead of waiting for spammers to give up each=20
time.

And, of course, if someone wants to ask a question, they could GET a=20
Yahoo account, or simply look through the message archives for an=20
answer to their question.

What does anyone else think?

Sadly, no monsters drop these. But you can still make decent weapons 
without them. This recipe works on dior wood and will produce 
similar results on most materials.

glow
dryad
glow
dryad
glow
aura
glow
aura
3 glow
2 shade
3 glow
2 wisp
glow
sala
glow
sala
glow
jinn
glow
jinn
3 glow
chaos
gnome
3 glow
chaos
gnome
3 glow
chaos
undine
3 glow
chaos
undine
2 glow
6 6 6 6 5 6 6 6

It's actually quite simple.  You only need to revisit the Hallway of 
Cartilage (the room where you had defeated Deathbringer the 
original) any time after defeating Jajara but before deafeating 
Drakonis (and thus clearing the Dragon Arc).  You'll see why when 
you fight him.

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Plunge Attack: Mjolnir Problems.
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=wFMk00DiYOmKSC_5_09vBPvJtp7GU9-s47wTdonBWEbBEuPu
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Thunder God requires 4 Wisp, 4 Salamander, and 4 Jinn at the time you 
temper the Electricity.
Since Aerolites drain Salamander each time you temper something, 
you'll need to make sure that you do indeed have 4 Salamander when you 
temper in the Electricity.

Double-check your essense values and try again. ^_^

Sincerely,
Myst Erik Ery

I believe the only length-related change between versions was the removal of the Pocketstation game "Ring Ring Land". If you're interested in that, I'm afraid I can't help you find it. However, let me set your mind at ease: no plot was taken out of the English version of the actual PSX portion. All intended plot removed was removed, for time constraints, from the Japanese version as well.

Shiyala

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "tim" <sketels2000@y...> wrote:
> hello, im trying to aquire the game shark codes to have infinate items 
> so that it makes it a lot easier to make and temper weapons and golems. 
> the problem seems to be that the code i have only gives me 99 
> menosbroze, which isnt all that useful. i have 3.3 cdx game shark and 
> the version five. the code i have been trying to use 5000ff010000  
> 300455b800ff does not seem to be the right code? help please or any way 
> to get all the items in large quanities would be much welcomed.

5000ff01 0000 is a serial repeater code that your gameshark isn't good
enough to handle. You'll have to change the quantity bytes for each
item you want individually.

I actually find item farming in LoM to be relaxing.

In the Japanese version, it is written using Katakana :
RU SHE I ME A (Rusheimea).

This would be pronounced like "Loo-shaay-may-uh" I suppose.

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Wicked Eyes
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=hZ1fS-dm7wj9rmqTgxeAVmp0fngxYhhK43vlwflqFYt0fTqO
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Wicked Eyes are the Rank 8 drop from Beholders, so it's as rare as 
Dragonscales and DiorWood.  I wouldn't recommend getting them from 
Beholders.

There are two Treasure Chests with Wicked Eyes in them (one in The 
Flames and one in the Junkyard) and you can also get them from the 
Shadow Zero-One Mini-game.

That would be the best place to get them, as you only need 51-60 
Zerobees (although that might be harder to get than the maximum, 200, 
just snag a 16-pointer three times (3*16 = 48) and then an 8 pointer 
(or less).

Acid (or possibly Blackened Bat, if you have 1+ Wisp) is a substitute 
for Wicked Eye, by the way, unless you need the Wicked Eye for its 
+25% Sharp, in which case Rhinoloupe or Spade Basil could work as 
well.  Acid is dropped by Big Baby and Slimes 50% of the time (when 
with a Polterbox - they also drop Fish Meat and Morph Meat).

I hope this helps.

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@y...> 
wrote:
> Wicked Eyes are the Rank 8 drop from Beholders, so it's as rare as 
> Dragonscales and DiorWood.  I wouldn't recommend getting them from 
> Beholders.
> 
> There are two Treasure Chests with Wicked Eyes in them (one in The 
> Flames and one in the Junkyard) and you can also get them from the 
> Shadow Zero-One Mini-game.
> 
> That would be the best place to get them, as you only need 51-60 
> Zerobees (although that might be harder to get than the maximum, 
200, 
> just snag a 16-pointer three times (3*16 = 48) and then an 8 
pointer 
> (or less).
> 
> Acid (or possibly Blackened Bat, if you have 1+ Wisp) is a 
substitute 
> for Wicked Eye, by the way, unless you need the Wicked Eye for its 
> +25% Sharp, in which case Rhinoloupe or Spade Basil could work as 
> well.  Acid is dropped by Big Baby and Slimes 50% of the time (when 
> with a Polterbox - they also drop Fish Meat and Morph Meat).
> 
> I hope this helps.
> 
> --- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "sparda659" <sparda659@y...> 
wrote:

such

in 
> > domina inn to see if that's any easier.  I think wicked eye is 
one

> > the prizes if you score within a certain range.

seeds the yggdrassil card appears rather than dryad.  Is it a mistake 
to use spiny seeds for this requirement?

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: the mirrored world
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=esl6shkgo1YdLKiVqU7MsDRVvDgg4TdnIwOmEQdz2u1X651e
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

"Any Seed" almost always means "Non-Spiny Seed".  Spiny Seed is the 
only seed that doesn't produce a Dryad Card, and is one of the hardest 
seeds to get.  We assume you'll use a seed you have plenty of, and use 
Spiny Seeds only where they are called for, as they are extremely 
useful in some parts of tempering (that is, you might as well use 
otherwise-useless items for something, and leave the items that do 
things for, well, WHEN they do things).

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "sparda659" <sparda659@y...> wrote:

> to use spiny seeds for this requirement?

Don't open it with Firefox then. Open it with IE, FireFox needs certain plugins for certain sites. Its a half-decent site in the making. I've maybe decided to continue with it and make it better. The link is http://www.freewebs.com/legendofmanaworld if you forgot.

Subject: Re: Help out a stumped jumi knight
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=IYYpafK2uzCh9sjM1-EpuvFhPoW8IOsA5dndC1P0OJB7V3bE

Buy AltenaFelt from a Level 4 Material Shop.  Check Gato's Student=20
Shop, Polpota's Student Shop, Lumina's Mummy Seeker Shop, and=20
Geo's "Hello Carl" Cafe Shop.  If it's not in any of those places,=20
you don't have a Level 4 Material Shop and will need to be more=20
careful with your Land placement next time, to ensure you get that=20
Material Shop.

For Sulpher, it's found in a Level 2 Material Shop.  Check the above=20
places, and hope that you've got such a shop available.

Rocket Papaya can only be grown by mixing Oblong Seeds (Yellow) with=20
Spiny Seeds, and are incredibly rare.

Subject: Re: I need ultimate recipes for Spears, armor, and capes!

Anything will do; even on the most difficult setting, Legend of Mana=20
is fairly easy, and could probably be beaten easily enough (albeit=20
with a great amount of patience) by someone wielding a 0 Attack Power=20
Flail at Level 1 with -40 to all stats (except for one: let's use HP,=20
since you can counter its HP-Regenerating powers by wearing particular=20
armor... so you have 65 HP Stat, but it does you no good), No HP Regen=20
Armor (AC 0), No Revive Armor (AC 0)...

For a nice spear, I would go with any of the uberrecipes, if you can=20
find the time to hunt the rare items required, or just go with a quick=20
recipe of some sort.

For Armor (and Mantles) there's one text file called, I believe, armor=20
basics, or something like that, which explains the routes you can take=20
for armor.

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Spam / Banning
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=iycVGymdNlh2r8RdHGWPVoMN5PrnV_W3q0V6Hp1G8CoVrh_U
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Hello, everyone!

I want to remind you all that spamming is expressly forbidden, and I=20
will ban any members who do so, spambot or not.

Also, in the future, please DO NOT REPLY to these spam messages.

I just accidentally banned the person whose name begins with an "x"=20
(sorry about that, I've removed the ban already) because I thought=20
it was a second identical spam message, since it had an extremely=20
similar Subject line and message text, before I realized it was=20
actually someone who felt the same way I do about these things ;)

I would love to make this group have moderated messages, but sadly I=20
don't have the time to check this group constantly for new messages,=20
and I want people to be able to post their questions and get quick=20
responses even if I am not online.

In the past, I had the group open to posts from anyone, but it=20
eventually was abused to the point where I had to make posting=20
members-only.  I don't want to go further than that - I hope for=20
this group to be open to everyone, but I also want it used for what=20
it was intended for!

The downside to keeping it unmoderated is that there are,=20
inevitably, going to be spambots or spammers.  All you need to do in=20
these cases is contact me (either online through Yahoo, or on AIM as=20
Myst Erik Ery) and I'll deal with the messages, if I haven't noticed=20
already :)

Here's hoping we can keep the group in good order!

(Also, a minor note: If anyone is afraid of getting nasty spam=20
messages in their email, simply change your contact settings to "No=20
Email" or "Announcements Only" , and check the new posts via the=20
group web site)

Sincerely,
JC "Myst Erik Ery" D
~ LoM Guru

Angel Feathers are dropped by Teedies and Garuda.  They are Rank 5=20
items, so you need them to be Level 16 before they'll drop them,=20
unless you're using a Polterbox.

You also earn one if you score 71 to 80 Zerobees at the Shadow Zero=20
Minigame.

- JC "Myst Erik Ery" D

Subject: Problems with the AltenaFelt Recipe.
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=aqZNVAoSURq5usutCxleRG4Ge7rAJLp1wbeQt5-n1Txloofb
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

I'm looking it over, and I've come across a few major problems.

#1.

 In Step D, nothing is accomplished...

	Aura Silver
	Mercury
	Fishy Fruit
	Mirror Piece
	Fire Stone
	4x Glow Crystal
	3x Sulpher
	Sala Gold
	Mush-in-a-Box

Draining Sala with the Fishy Fruit is a good idea, but with only one
Wizard Card, Aura's Resistance of 9 is only down to 6, meaning it
requires 2^9 * 6 energy to get to Level 10 ( 3072 ), whereas draining
Salamander from 9->8 releases 2^8 * 10 energy ( 2560 )... so the
energy goes back into Salamander (as its Taint is dealt with before
Undine can become a problem) and then Undine raises to 1...  Then you
use a Mirror Piece (ouch!) and a Firestone to drain Undine back to
0... and then uselessly pop in 4 Glow Crystals + 3 Sulphur + Sala Gold
to "get Sala back to 9" (when really it already got itself back to 9),
and then raise Shade once with the Mush-in-a-Box.

#2. Step G to E.

 Immediately following most "Repeat Step G" (and in fact the initial
Step G) is "Repeat Step E" ... let's take a look.

Step G:
	Corn Flower
	Mercury
	2x Aura Silver
	Fishy Fruit
	Chaos Crystal
	Lilapod
	Mush-in-a-Box
Step E:=20
	Mirror Piece
	2x Sulpher
	Fire Stone
	Honey Onion
	Mercury
	Garlic Crown

So let's look at the last little bit of Step G.

(Spring)Aura/Aura/Witch  +Chaos Crystal
(Ancient Moon)Spring/Aura/Aura   +Lilipods
(Enticed Nymph)Ancient Moon/Spring/Aura  + Mush-in-a-Box
(Enticed Nymph)Ancient Moon/Spring/Aura  + Mirror Piece
(---)Enticed Nymph/Ancient Moon/Spring  !!!!

You see, a Mirror piece is being used for naught!  And thus, you're
not getting the effects of the Mirrored World Card, either...

#3.  Many of those element counters seem to be off... and the end of
Step G, you should have 2 Shade if everything is working the way you'd
really want them to (and in fact you WANT to end with 2 Shade, as far
as I can tell), but it says you'd only have 1 Shade.

:( I don't even want to try to find more errors...

What's up with that?  How have these things gone unnoticed for so
long?  o_O  I could've sworn I've made a cloth spear, too, but maybe I
never actually bothered.  Others have made them, yes?  If so, what's
up, here? O_o=20

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=264703450; y=1cSei2yB2f4VvblQUGu4CkYUc56OB4COP2WWoqLMshBKr4ad1A
X-Yahoo-Profile: xotektwist

Has anyone calculated the best weapon type/level combo to maximize=20
character stats?  The best I can come up with is 2 Hammer, 9 Staff, and=20
87 Sword levels which will bring the character to level 99 (the=20
character starts at level 1).  This combo results in 99 Power, 99=20
Skills, 99 Defense, 84 Magic, 76 HP, 78 Spirit, and 84 Charm for a=20
grand total of 619 Stat Pts (not including Luck which is static).

A straight Sword level up scheme for 98 levels (the character starts at=20
level 1) results in 99 Power, 99 Skills, 99 Defense, 78 Magic, 78 HP,=20
78 Spirit, and 84 Charm for a grand total of 609 Stat Pts.

The first method sacrifices -2 HP Stat Pts in exchange for +6 Magic and=20
+6 Charm Stat Pts, which is a better deal overall.

Is there another combo I'm missing which improves the numbers better=20
than my first method?

There were a topic on the subject some months ago on gamefaqs ; I run some =
number, and found the following combos:
------------------------
=3D=3DVilurum's combo:=3D=3D
------------------------
82 Sword
8 Glove
6 Staff
2 Axe

Result: 99 Power, 99 Skills, 99 Defense, 79 Magic, 79 HP, 79 Spirit, 81 Cha=
rm

------------------
=3D=3DMy Results:=3D=3D
------------------

Everything  >=3D 74 (+5 base =3D 79):=20
1 Knife, 81 Sword, 1 Axe, 6 Staff, 9 Glove ;
PWR 97
(+5 base =3D 99)
SKL 94 (+1/4)
(+5 base =3D 99)
DEF 94
(+5 base =3D 99)
MGC 74 (+ 1/4)=20
(+5 base =3D 79)
HP 74
(+5 base =3D 79)
SPT 74
(+5 base =3D 79)
CHM 76 (+ 1/2)
(+5 base =3D 81)
Sum (+base) =3D 615

Everything >=3D 77 (+5 base =3D 82):
14 Sword, 14 Axe, 28 Staff, 42 Glove ;
PWR 94 (+ 1/2)
(+5 base =3D 99)
SKL 77
(+5 base =3D 82)
DEF 80 (+ 1/2)
(+5 base =3D 85)
MGC 77
(+5 base =3D 82)
HP 77
(+5 base =3D 82)
SPT 77
(+5 base =3D 82)
CHM 84
(+5 base =3D 89)
Sum (+base) =3D 601

no solution for everything >=3D 78 (+5 base =3D83);

Best stat average with integer values:
1 Knife, 82 Sword, 1 Axe,  1 Hammer; 13 Staff;=20
PWR 92
(+5 base =3D 97)
SKL 94 (+1/2)
(+5 base =3D 99)
DEF 94
(+5 base =3D 99)

(+5 base =3D 85)
HP 70
(+5 base =3D 75)

(+5 base =3D 79)
CHM 80
(+5 base =3D 85)
Sum (+base) =3D 619

Always: 93.0 or higher HP

Set 1: highest total sum of stats

Theorical (with floating values for levels and stats below 99) solution:
78 Glove
20 Bow

Result:
99.0 PWR (107.5 + 5)
98.5 SKL (93.5 + 5)
78.5 DEF (73.5 + 5)
59.0 MGC (54 + 5)
93.0 HP_ (88 + 5)
78.5 SPT (73.5 + 5)
83.5 CHM (78.5 + 5)

TOTAL: 590

Practical (integer values) solution:
02 Sword
77 Glove
19 Bow

Result:
99 PWR (107.75 + 5)
98 SKL (93 + 5)
79 DEF (74 + 5)
59 MGC (54.25 + 5)
93 HP_ (88 + 5)
78 SPT (73.5 + 5)
83 CHM (78.25 + 5)

TOTAL: 589

I couldn't find a solution with 590 total (that doesn't mean it doesn't exi=
st). I'm disappointed I couldn't drain more PWR to shove it somewhere else,=
 but it may be impossible (I'm counting on you guys to tell me if it's impo=
ssible) ; and the one point lost to truncation in the in the other stats bo=
thers me as well

Set 2: highest possible sum of power/skills (prioritizing in order after th=
at: defense, then magic, then sum of spirit/charm)
It's not simple to setup that in a single simplex... Let's see

Theorical highest value of the sum: dunno, the tool forfeited after not bei=
ng able to provide a solution ofter 50 steps... :/
My guess, from some tests I done, is that the higher value is 197 (99 + 98)=
, as displayed in the above example, and there is very little rooms for imp=
rovements.

I admit my failure to provide a definitive answer here. I'll try again once=
 I'll have found more powerful tools.

P.S. : by tweaking the results a bit (it seems the tool is somewhat... sens=
ible to the fact that some variables are ignored), I obtained the same resu=
lt as the above theorical solution: maximum value for PWR + SKL =3D 197.5, =
197 rounding down. And the best solution I found is the same as the one dis=
played... It may be a bug.

I tried going as far as a difference of 3 levels (for each weapon) from the=
 theorical solution, and found nothing better... yet.

--------------------------
=3D=3D some other results =3D=3D
--------------------------
Optimum HP is 93. At 93 HP, you regain the maximum of 30 HP per second. Com=
pare that to the next lowest range of 89-92, where you only regain 15 HP pe=
r second. As you go further down, it gets even more pathetic: 85-88 is 10 H=
P per second, 81-84 is 7.5 HP per second, 77-80 is 6 HP per second...

No results for HP>93, all other stats >79 (already said).
No result either for HP>89, all other stats >79.
BUT:
HP>85, all other stats >79

Best average (theoretical) solution:
14 Sword
02 Axe
28 Staff
54 Glove

Objet : [LoM Kitchen] Max Character Stats

   Has anyone calculated the best weapon type/level combo to maximize=20
 character stats?  The best I can come up with is 2 Hammer, 9 Staff, and=20
 87 Sword levels which will bring the character to level 99 (the=20
 character starts at level 1).  This combo results in 99 Power, 99=20
 Skills, 99 Defense, 84 Magic, 76 HP, 78 Spirit, and 84 Charm for a=20
 grand total of 619 Stat Pts (not including Luck which is static).
=20
 A straight Sword level up scheme for 98 levels (the character starts at=20
 level 1) results in 99 Power, 99 Skills, 99 Defense, 78 Magic, 78 HP,=20
 78 Spirit, and 84 Charm for a grand total of 609 Stat Pts.
=20
 The first method sacrifices -2 HP Stat Pts in exchange for +6 Magic and=20
 +6 Charm Stat Pts, which is a better deal overall.
=20
 Is there another combo I'm missing which improves the numbers better=20
 than my first method?

> So, why wouldn't you want to use something like Adamantite for=20
high=20
> essence levels?  Isn't it's offense power still superior to that=20
of=20
> Diorwood or Dragon Scales?  I dunno, I'm just looking at=20
> material.txt by tagged_jc:
>=20
> GC | Sh He Fo Te | St Sl Pi MD | Wi Sh Dr Au Sa Gn Ji Un
> --------------------------------------------------------
> 20 | 62 46 93 99 | 62 31 93 62 |  8  8  8  8  8  8  8  8 |=20
Adamantite
> 10 | 50 30 70 20 | 80 25 35 45 |  7  8  5  9 10  7  7  7 | DiorWood
> 14 | 60 66 54 54 | 72 72 60 30 |  7  7  7  7  6  7  7  7 |=20
DragonScal
>=20
> As I see it, Adamantite seems to have the best stats, and really=20
> only 4 more essence resistance points than DiorWood.  Or is it=20
just=20
> that with Essences Maxed out like in the Uber Recipes those stats=20
> become essentially meaningless?  And in that case, wouldn't that=20
> Aeriolite recipe with the some 116 total essence points end up=20
being=20
> the best material to use?


Adamanatite is worse than DiorWood and DragonScales for high-essence=20
tempering because of that first number.  That number determines how=20
much essence levels raise the attack value, and a higher number=20
means that each essence level has LESS effect.  With the same number=20
of essence levels, DiorWood would have twice the multiplier from=20
essence levels compared to Adamantite.

Its rediculously easy to make money in this game, as soon as you get
the blacksmith, that is.  In Luon Highway, kill the floaty-squid
things for the hat they drop, then kill the wasp-monsters for the
clear feathers.  Dump four clear feathers into the hat and sell it in
town.  The hat goes for 26k+ every time.  Also, DragonBone pendants
with 2 Blackened Bats, enough to get a wings of darkness card.  Those
sell for like, 20k if not more too.

Actually, Muramasa is yet another legendary sword.

Masamune, Muramasa, Murasame.

Masamune: Widely recognized as Japan's greatest swordsmith.
Muramasa: Another swordsmith, Masamune's apprentice and said to have=20
been a bit insane.
Murasame: A fictional sword from the Japanese 19th century novel=20
Nans=F4 Satomi Hakkenden

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masamune
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muramasa
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murasame

Tada!

Kingdoms Hearts II :)

From: tf_faq <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
Reply-To: no_reply@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [LoM Kitchen] Re: The Evil Sword Murasame...
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=174770107; y=8sApX9CYRoqBUcLpfYWzA9ubsSCurFeiwsoGu9IFr7ur; email=no
X-Yahoo-Profile: tf_faq

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Myers" <Otakusensei@...> wrote:
>
> Muramasa and Murasame are the same thing, check out the wikipedia.
> Squaresoft has used both in various games, I just got a Masamune-G in
> Kingdoms Hearts II :)

Wrong.  Muramasa and Murasame are *NOT* the same thing.  Many people
*CONFUSE* them, hence why it says that Muramasa is sometimes
incorrectly called Murasame.  But that doesn't make them the same -
see, Japanese companies tend not to confuse the two.

> > --- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@>
wrote:
> > >
> > > Actually, Muramasa is yet another legendary sword.
> > >
> > > Masamune, Muramasa, Murasame.
> > >
> > > Masamune: Widely recognized as Japan's greatest swordsmith.
> > > Muramasa: Another swordsmith, Masamune's apprentice and said to have
> > > been a bit insane.

Not Masamune's apprentice.  There's a good couple of centuries between
Masamune and Muramasa's time.  And Muramasa's infamy is more linked to
the Tokugawa Shogunate banning the use of Muramasa blades, due to
numerous accidents and incidents that Tokugawa Ieyasu and his
relatives experienced regarding them.

> > > Murasame: A fictional sword from the Japanese 19th century novel
> > > Nans=F4 Satomi Hakkenden

And yes, this is what Murasame always refers to.  The Hakkenden is a
particularly famous and *LONG* novel, and the Murasame itself has a
role that is very similar to Arthurian Legend's Sword in the Stone - a
blade that was said to only be usable by the true rule of the Kantoo
region.

So.  Masamune and Muramasa?  Real life historical blades that have no
real life relation to each other (the comparisons sprang up during
fiction and plays written during the Tokugawa era, since Masamune was
still hailed as the best, and Muramasa was hated by the shogunate).=20
Murasame?  Fictional blade, no known swordsmith of that name.  And
uniquely, a single named blade, rather than just a shorthand meaning
"A sword by <swordsmith>"

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Uber Equipment
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=DUPKdhGCzHSNssp1cOnJ5E7ANUOUrydo0M6FOokEfl45BTwT
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Yes; simply use the DragonScales uberrecipe for any Dragonscales=20
weapons.  All weapons temper the same up until the very, very end.=20=20
That's when you use what's called a "varnish" which *IS* weapon-
specific (and often material-specific, too).

Check varnish.txt to see what varnish is best for YOUR weapon/material=20
combination.  :)

For example, making a DragonScales staff would have you end with 3=20
Holy Water, (one card-creating item to push in the Cleric Card) and a=20
Giant's Horn.

varnish for 999.

hit 999 attackpower and you get to keep the +9stats.

could never fix it was at the very beginning when you initially level=20
up Sala.  Basically getting all the enegy that was put into the gnome=20
for the plunge attack "assisted" sala gains.  So if you tried the=20
recipe on any other type of weapon I think it woulda came up one sala=20
shot with an improper card order when you got around to raising the=20
2nd essence.  I could never fix it though cause SOMEONE decided to put=20

From: "DragonBlood87" <dragonblood87@adelphia.net>
Subject: Re: Newbie question!
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=267010047; y=CKRV9MeUJmILIairMIEQY86zm17D1_F7dWJPUpT7WgxInEIViXE
X-Yahoo-Profile: czilligen87

A "card item" is any item that will produce a card when tempered into=20
equipment; the card doesn't show up until another card item is=20
tempered in.

Spiny Seeds are a rare drop of Lullabuds, Shrieknips, and Malboros.=20
You will want to be using a Polterbox while item hunting (if you kill=20
something while you are standing next to a pet polterbox, you will=20
have a much better chance of getting rare items).

Chances of getting Spiny Seeds from the above monsters:
(Note: 'Level' is monster's level)
With polterbox:
Levels 1-15 =3D 12.5% (16/128, or 1 in 8)
Levels 16+ =3D 6.25% (8/128, or 1 in 16)
Without polterbox:
Levels 1-31: 0.0%
Levels 32-47: 3.125% (4/128, or 1 in 32)
Levels 48+: 1.5625% (2/128, or 1 in 64)

From Wikipedia:

"The PocketStation is a miniature game console created by Sony as a=20
peripheral for the PlayStation. Released exclusively in Japan on=20
December 23, 1998 [...]"

"Although the system was not released in North America or Europe,=20
there were apparently plans to do so - a feature on the system=20
appeared in Official UK PlayStation Magazine, for example, and a few=20
games (such as Final Fantasy VIII) retained PocketStation=20
functionality in their localised versions. As a result, the PC version=20
of Final Fantasy VIII added a stand-alone Chocobo World game as part=20
of the installation."

Sorry, but unless you are using the Japanese or PC versions of the=20
games (and consoles), I'm pretty sure you can't use a Pocketstation.

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "laike_endaril"=20
<SilverTallon@...> wrote:
> If the sum of the numbers for=20
> the same stat is over the limit (98 for hero and 20 on a weapon or=20
> something), does the game cap the sum off at 99, or can you have=20
> higher than 99 with bonuses from equipment?

You can have higher than 99 with bonuses from equipment; some stats=20
have a prime point; for example, the HP Stat gives you the best HP=20
Regeneration at 97 HP Stat (I believe?) , so anything more than that=20
is unnecessary except for resistance to poison and for resistance=20
against certain other attacks and such.


--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "William"=20
<masterofdimensions@...> wrote:
> I'm not all entirely sure if I misread this somewhere, but what are
> the appropriate varnishes for any given weapon type?

In the files section there is a file called "varnish.txt".

This file contains all the information you'll ever need to know=20
about which varnishes to use for which weapon/material combintion ---
 it's different for each weapon/material, since it affects the=20
material's values, which in turn are affected by the weapon's values=20
to get the final Offense Power.
In addition, this file shows the power of that weapon made of that=20
material with the maximum amount of essences possible on that=20
material (and at 0 essences) so you can compare strengths.

So sorry about that!
I really only frequent here every so often, so if it starts getting=20
bad, you really have to post a message on the GameFAQs board about=20
it: http://boards.gamefaqs.com/gfaqs9/gentopic.php?board=3D256525
I frequent that board, so that would be a great way to get ahold of=20
me if I'm not on your AIM friend list.

One minor note:

Make sure that if you DO make a Reply to the spammers... CHANGE THE=20
SUBJECT LINE!
I don't know how many times I've nearly banned someone by accident=20
because they had the same text in their message and I almost didn't=20
notice that it was simply quoted...
Please don't reply directly to the spammers, thank you! :)

Again, sorry for all that mess :( It's bad of me.


ALSO NOTE: I've fixed the Aerolite recipe, as requested :P You do=20
know you could have just, I dunno, made a second copy?

ALSO NOTE: The Calc program does Aerotites wrong.  Newly-forged=20
Aerolites should come with 4 Salamander Essence.

Thank you all for your patience!

From: "vaine_bekonnes" <vainebekonnes@sbcglobal.net>
Subject: Theoretical vs. Actual
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=244411170; y=wRdoeDqbBEtHwJIh8cTotqnJIrEa7BzvCcbYBfySiNmbnDZ4lzbMesUAXoeGuCKYS7zBmVuE
X-Yahoo-Profile: vaine_bekonnes
X-eGroups-Approved-By: tagged_jc <tagged_jc@yahoo.com> via web; 11 Mar 2007 16:19:44 -0000

I bought Legend of Mana when it first came out and played through it a=20
couple of times.  I played around with tempering, getting a rough idea=20
on how some of it worked and then I stopped playing the game.  Here it=20
is years later, I pick the game back up deciding to take it a bit more=20
seriously.  Here I find that the art of tempering has been advanced=20
greatly from the intial conception and the mathematics behind the=20
system have been layed out by various players.  Between the weapon=20
basics file, the material chart file, and the beginning essences file,=20
everything seems to make sense.  That is, at first glance everything=20
seems to make sense.

Regarding essences however there seems to be a disconnect on how high=20
essence totals can get in various materials.  Some recipes and files=20
proudly proclaim totals as high as 15 in certain elements, while others=20
claim that it is theoretically impossible to get higher than 10 in a=20
single element.  How is one supposed to discern the truth in the myriad=20
of opinions.  Does anyone know the validity of various essence theories=20
in actual practice, or is a lot of this theoretical?  Any illumination=20
in the matter would be greatly appreciated.

From: SYDNEY SCHAFFER <sariosyd@shaw.ca>
Subject: Re: [LoM Kitchen] Theoretical vs. Actual
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=106369500; y=XXrz5yp2hoVNGpu9Oei2YBoZWrKXkieH1Yl_tFIO_Is2Ig
X-Yahoo-Profile: shiyala

I know very little about Tempering, but as I check my e-mail more regularly than most, allow me to welcome you to the Kitchen.

As for essence totals, I have seen items with 15 in some elements, though I believe it is impossible in practice to obtain 15 in all of them at once. The reason some guides state that it is impossible to get over 10 is most likely that they are simply old guides, developed before Tempering was fully understood.

Keep in mind, I might be wrong. Anyone, feel free to correct me on this!

Shidoni

> is years later, I pick the game back up deciding to take it a bit 
> more 
> seriously.  Here I find that the art of tempering has been advanced 
> greatly from the intial conception and the mathematics behind the 
> system have been layed out by various players.  Between the weapon 
> basics file, the material chart file, and the beginning essences 
> file, 
> everything seems to make sense.  That is, at first glance 
> everything 
> seems to make sense.
> 
> Regarding essences however there seems to be a disconnect on how 
> high 
> essence totals can get in various materials.  Some recipes and 
> files 
> proudly proclaim totals as high as 15 in certain elements, while 
> others 
> claim that it is theoretically impossible to get higher than 10 in 
> a 
> single element.  How is one supposed to discern the truth in the 
> myriad 
> of opinions.  Does anyone know the validity of various essence 
> theories 
> in actual practice, or is a lot of this theoretical?  Any 
> illumination 
> in the matter would be greatly appreciated.

I'm not a genius in tempering by any means but from what I understand=20
mirror pieces are used to get the card mirror world. Mirror world=20
reverses domininance. IIRC the top row of elements have dominance over=20
the lower row which allows the top row to consume energy already in=20
the bottom row to level up past level 10. Mirror world would allow the=20
bottom row to consume energy from the opposing top row element.

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Theoretical vs. Actual
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=bzENtEaexQhw6TstQ3-NfnRK5Uy1QUy0zHSc4h_DvhoypiqF
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Hopefully I can clear some of this up.

Mirrored World does indeed reverse dominance.  However, the
"upper-row" essences do not dominate the "lower-row" ones.

Under normal conditions:
Wisp can always rise.
Shade cannot rise if Wisp is present.
Dryad cannot rise if Aura is present and [Shade>Wisp] is true.
Aura cannot rise if Dryad is present and [Wisp>Shade] is true.
Salamander cannot rise if Undine is present.
Gnome cannot rise if Salamander is present.
Jinn cannot rise if Gnome is present.
Undine cannot rise if Jinn is present.

You'll notice there's two sets here.  The "lower-row" essences
(Salamander, Gnome, Jinn, Undine) are simply cyclic.  This is why you
can always raise two of them without conflict provided the other two
are at zero (Salamander and Jinn, or Gnome and Undine) because they do
not interfere with each other.

The "upper-row" essences are a bit stranger.  Wisp and Shade are a
dual, but Wisp is always able to rise, whereas it is better to begin
by raising Shade as it cannot rise once you begin to raise Wisp.
Dryad and Aura depend on Wisp and Shade.
Dryad, the being of life and thus associated with light, requires Wisp
dominance.
Aura, the being of metal and thus associated with darkness, requires
Shade dominance.

Mirrored World simply reverses these effects.
The "lower-row" is backwards: Undine cannot rise if Salamander is
present, and so on.
The "upper-row" is backwards: Wisp cannot rise if Shade is present
(but Shade can always rise)... and Dryad now depends on Shade
dominance, whereas Aura depends on Wisp dominance.

The reason high-level tempering uses Mirrored World is to "slosh" energy.

When draining (which has ever-so-slightly different rules than simply
being able to raise an essence, but which is also reversed with
Mirrored World) , you can often raise two essences at once at the cost
of only one essence point.

Effectively, you'll be "sloshing" energy back and forth between Aura
and Dryad.
Let's say you have 0 Wisp, 15 Shade, 14 Aura, 15 Dryad, 14 Salamander,
and 14 Jinn.
You can see that this is ready to "slosh".

When you drain Dryad (using Aura, which you can do, since Shade>Wisp)
and provide a Jinn TP (and have enough Wizard cards present: both Jinn
and Aura use Witch, which is why we're raising Jinn and not Salamander)...
Aura -> 15
Dryad -> 14
Jinn -> 15

So now we have 0/15/15/14/14/0/15/0.

Now, making sure we don't just drain Dryad down to 0 (which is why we
use things like Garlicrowns, which only provide an Aura taint point
once, thus preventing residual drains), we want to raise Salamander.
How?
Well, now we utilize Mirrored World.
If we can drain while under the effects of Mirrored World, we can have
Dryad drain Aura (instead of vice-versa) with Shade>Wisp.

Thus, since Dryad and Salamander are both being raised, we can get
away with using Sorcerer.

So really, Mirrored World doesn't help with raising limits in and of
itself - it just allows you to "slosh" energy back and forth, allowing
spillover energy to raise the lower-row essences.

There are two ways you can get Ishe Platinum.  You can receive it for=20
accomplishing missions later in the game after you have exhausted=20
artifacts, and you can also buy it from a shop if you place the city=20
late enough in the game.

Hello,

OK this will sound ridiculous, this is the simplest of questions...=20
The ultimate newbie question.

I have the springball pet and I leveled him up to 25.  Then i went
back home, filled his box with food and left him in the barn to eat.

I walk around the world map to make days pass by.  When i returned to
my house and checked on my pet, the box was still full.....

So i ventured out again, walk around the world multiple times, and
always returned to find the box full.

Can anyone please let me know what I've done wrong?  I've pretty much
done everything else in the game, but I've never touched the pet
section before...:s i saved it for last...

So my question is, what are the exact procedures for feeding your pet?

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: How do you feed your pet?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=BWJsUc-u-DTGO9tf4D7_Ac9taiS2qgcjjo1QSmG-YglTnSPH
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Level it up once.

Pets eat only when they gain a level, and they eat everything in their
food box.

Thus, you only have 98 opportunities to feed your pet, and that's only
if you can remember to get back to the corral to add more feed before
you level it up a second time by mistake.

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: sharing exp
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=XqVxocMUW5KQwsN9kyh-9Qbsz4q0yg8519wrwR94gX6ACq0X
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Yes.  A Ring or Pendant with the Fertility Goddess effect will cause
all experience you pick up to be shared.  Alternately, you can use the
ForbiddenRing earned by completing "The Wisdom of Gaeus".

Also, if you have your pet grazing in the corral, it will receive free
experience proportional to the experience you gain while it's grazing.

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: sharing exp
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=9gK_tVY9_zONlcdpw11gMKElEbl1Y-YzUFsDnObrKkDZvvfT
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Only Rings and Pendants can have the Fertility Goddess effect.  Simply
add the Fertility Goddess Mystic Card (which requires 5 Dryad essence,
and the Ear of Wheat item, plus something to push the Fertility
Goddess onto the piece of equipment).  Just don't add any other
effects after, and it'll be the Effect of your equipment (for example,
adding the "No HP Regen" Effect of Bed of Thorn will overwrite the
"Share Exp" effect of the Fertility Goddess).

Just wear the ring or pendant, and voila!

If you want the effect to end, just take off the ring or pendant.  You
can remove it from the ring or pendant only by replacing it with
another Effect, but that's not too hard, either, if you really wanted
to do so.

X-Yahoo-Post-IP: 24.67.76.34
From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: legend of mana PSP
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=GRZDL8-lRO8kjmbJLhp-9Weo34Vo8v80vUiB-veketnEiRqd
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Being on PSP won't change how you learn STs.

Each ST has a required value for Weaponskill and Abilityskills.

Every battle you are in, you get one Weaponskill point for the weapon
you have equipped, and one Abilityskill point for each ability you
have set.  You don't have to actually use the abilities, just have
them equipped for that battle.

Once you go past the threshold to learn a new ability or ST, you'll do
so.  So, just equip the right weapon, and use the required abilities
(switching them around if the ST requires multiple abilities, until
you learn it).

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "rei075" <rei075@...> wrote:
>
> Hi, I was wondering, if I have legend of mana on PSP how will I be=20
> able to learn & do special move like karma ?

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Allo!
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=2kz3WsDL6CHVgs14UEp1y708tV8EoTYMMAOL4anyirSBJWYA
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

The first three numbers means the Mystic Cards, and the final number
is the "capper" item.

2222 means you want to end with three Cleric Cards on your equipment,
and cap it with a Giant's Horn.
You could go 4 Holy Water + Giant's Horn , to make sure you have the
three Cleric Cards (if you only use three Holy Water, you will
probably end up with only 2 Cleric Cards, as one will be in the
invisible slot --- Giant's Horn doesn't add a Mystic Card unless you
have certain essences).

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@...>=20
wrote:
>
> Being on PSP won't change how you learn STs.
>=20
> Each ST has a required value for Weaponskill and Abilityskills.
>=20
> Every battle you are in, you get one Weaponskill point for the=20
weapon
> you have equipped, and one Abilityskill point for each ability you
> have set.  You don't have to actually use the abilities, just have
> them equipped for that battle.
>=20
> Once you go past the threshold to learn a new ability or ST,=20
you'll do
> so.  So, just equip the right weapon, and use the required=20
abilities
> (switching them around if the ST requires multiple abilities, until
> you learn it).
>=20

Evarastral, I had a real problem with earning cash in the game at
first (at best in a game you only get 10-20 grand and thats searching)
 But I saw on a guide way back when that you can combine a wind cap
with 4 bug wings( I think thats what they are called) and you get
22000 lucre,  It's the only way i was able to afford all the glow and
chaos crystals necessary for the better equipment.  All that stuff can
be gotten at luon highway (though the bug wings can take a little
while)  Hope that helps you get some of those weapons you have been eying!

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Allo!
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=yU9YYRuJ-1wh8fy4T21TB2lE-GJRWOBNg2zDiVK2ATzuRwl_
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

No store-bought way of making a lot of money (that would be too easy!).

WindCap are dropped by Spiny Cones quite often, whereas Clear Feathers
are dropped by Stinger Bees.  Both are found on the Luon Highway.

If you temper four Clear Feathers into a WindCap, it will sell for
26667 Lucre.  That should be plenty! :)

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: chocobo legend of mana PSP
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=oYE8qpqRZt-DqdC8kpExWGvubQbZBBsjTFR4xU53UhmM5nT3
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

There are five ranks of monster for each classification (check your
Monster Encyclopedia, they're listed in order!), except for
Poltergeist (it only has four) and Demi-Human (as they don't come from
eggs.

The higher the rank, the harder it is to get that monster's egg unless
you place the land you find them in far from Home.  So you're going to
have an extremely difficult time finding one at Luon Highway if you
placed it near Home, but an easier time at Lake Kilma if you place it
further away.

You won't be able to tell what rank of monster it is from any given
egg, though you can sometimes tell what monster is inside by looking
at your egg's Offense and HP scores (which it tells you before it
hatches).

These values are the same as the level 1 monster's stats.  Thus, if
you catch plenty of Aerial Eggs, you can figure out which one is a
chocobo by looking at your Aerial Eggs (either go to sell a pet
monster when you find too many eggs, or check back at your corral) and
seeing if any have the stats of a level 1 chocobo (or, instead, just
sell the ones that have duplicate stats as an Aerial Monster you
already have that isn't a chocobo).

From: "deskanar" <deskanar@msn.com>
Subject: Re: Silver/Gold
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=199532155; y=uuCkhucKSFtRJCM2cCCpsvyX6yYNQloCb2WvumzS2ON7OYQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: deskanar
X-eGroups-Approved-By: tagged_jc <tagged_jc@yahoo.com> via web; 27 Nov 2007 08:39:49 -0000

Gato Grottos will allow you to collect coins faster than any other
place; in the egg/spirit room there, the spirits are slightly closer
than normal. This allows you to skip the music-playing minigame and
simply run quickly to the closer spirit, grabbing coins from it before
it can vanish on you.

If you need specific coins, raise the element levels you need in the
Grottos to make those spirits show up more often; otherwise, try
maxing out all of its elemental properties by placing the Tree of Mana
next to it, for a good chance of any spirit appearing there.

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "pspsuck90" <pspsuck90@...> wrote:
>
> it is true that u cant conitue after killing the mana goddess.,?
>
after killing the mana goddess you can continue playing, since that is the
only way to get enough mirror pieces for the big recipes. I am unsure how
it works on the psp (I assume thats what you're playing on) but in the PS1
version you were given the option to save after beating her, loading that
save started the game over with levels, pets, and items carried over.

Off the top of my head I know the following mirror piece locations:
- In Elle's cage at Madora Beach
- On the first level of the Jewel City in a jewel room (I forget which one =
but it was blue)
- In the Mana Tree's sanctuary, I think in the middle room of the northeast=
 side

Not sure if there are more than that but I remembered those.

> Im not so sure what a plunge attacks is, could someone explain it to=20
> me please ?
>

A plunge attack are those attacks you do when you do a thrust=20
forward/attack, a jump forward/attack, and then when you swing your=20
blade up in an uppercut manner/attack. I cant remember exactly how to=20
execute them, but i do know that prior to press SQUARE, your movement=20
is what determines the plunge attack you use.. if you move backwards=20
then forward quickly then press SQUARE, then you will execute the=20
jumping plunge attack, that is the only 1 i can remember how to do off=20
the top of my head.

From: "Erik Randolph" <errickfoxy@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: [LoM Kitchen] What's plunge attacks ?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=196770274; y=7sIL2RbfmtXHJbAYwIKSAGirn0yuZQ4cEO2DO0fxsA8oT1wchw
X-Yahoo-Profile: hewhoyerfs
X-Yahoo-Newman-Property: groups-system
X-eGroups-Approved-By: tagged_jc <tagged_jc@yahoo.com> via web; 25 Mar 2008 06:00:35 -0000

Plunge attacks are the attacks you do when you tap certain directional
buttons before hitting the strong attack button. There's three, as far
as I recall. Tappping twice in a direction gets you a lunging attack
on most weapons, tapping left-right or right-left gets you a leaping
attack, and doing what I always thought of as the fireball motion
(roll from down to either left or right) gets you an upward swing that
knocks enemies back.

When it comes to the crafting stuff though, you can replace the plunge
attacks with special ones.  The attack animation is the same, but
they'll have various special effects.  I didn't even knew they existed
though, these special ones, until long after I stopped playing. :)

From: "Myst Erik Ery" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: +20 all stats?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=q-qrldTgrycJVJi4vBP6Fg0oR4sur7N5GAoY1VVLggblLcW7
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

You're very close.

Limitations are indeed set by the card with the best limitations - in
this case, the only -10 ~ +20 cards are the Evil God cards, as you
mentioned.

However, the Evil God cards also apply a -1 to all stats as their
"bonus", which means you'll be hard pressed to actually get to +20!

This is why two Yggdrasil cards are usually used: Yggdrasil's bonus is
+1 all, so it can countereffect the Evil God card's detrimental effect
if you have one. Thus, with one Yggdrasil, you're gaining +0 each
tempering step, which still isn't enough to level it up. This is where
you either throw in a second Yggdrasil (making sure it applies *after*
the Evil God's -1, or you get to +15 maximum since that last boost can
never fully apply, as you go from [14] (+15) to [15] (+20) from the
first Yggrasil, and then from to [15] (+20) to [15] (+20) with the
second Yggdrasil, and then from [15] (+20) to [14] (+15) from the Evil
God Card... hence why the order is important!) or you can temper in
items like Dragon's Blood or Toadstoolshed (which have a bonus of +1
all)... though those two might cause you card problems, depending on
material type and current essences (which is why the double-Yggrasil
method is so prominent).


.... and armor.doc is in the Files section, I believe, rei075.
Make sure when you post messages, you put the message ABOVE the reply,
or at least WITHOUT the preceding ">" mark, since otherwise people
think it's part of the original message.

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "bloodly_shiva" <Tolaburke@...> wrote:
>
> --- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "underworldlegion"=20
> <underworldlegion@y...> wrote:
> > Ok I'm pretty sure about this but I just want to make sure.  Is the=20
> > reason for getting +20 stats because you have 2 yggdrasil cards and=20
> > each allows a +10 max across the board and together is +20?  Im=20
> > trying to make a +20 all stat all status protectio pendent with=20
> > quite high mdef, all though I'm sure the one in the armor.doc is=20
> the=20
> > result of countless hours of striving for the same thing.
>=20
> No.
>=20
> This is a theory, but I THINK it's accurate, from what I've read.=20=20
> Can someone confirm?
>=20
> With limits, the highest possible applies.  They don't combine as you=20
> suggest.  The Cards that give the highest limits are the cards from=20
> the '7 Evil Gods' set-Fallen Angel, Witch of Moon, Lord of Flies,=20
> Wings of Darkness, God of Destruction, Beast-Headed God, and=20
> Leviathan.  Their limits are -10 to +20 to stats.  Their effect on=20
> attributes is to raise one stat by 15, but put the rest down.
>=20
> The way the recipies for stat equips work is to combine one of those=20
> cards with Yggdrassil, which allows items tempered in to raise stats=20
> as long as the card is present.  Thus allowing you to hit the maximum=20
> limit via items that don't produce cards, like Meat.
>=20
> I think having two Yggdrassils is to double the amount tempering an=20
> item raises stats by.
>

Are you playing on a ROM?  If so, you *theoretically* could play with
two players (because it's the exact same game as the playstation
version, and you can play with two players there)... however, that
would depend on your emulator and how it works.  If the emulator
supports multiple players, you can. Otherwise, you can't.

I noticed in another post recently it was said that there is no=20
store-bought method to make money.  I had never really thought about=20
looking for one before, but now I was curious...

I fumbled around with some recipes and whatnot, and I came up with=20
something.
Make a weapon using this recipe...

ToppleCotton: 60 Lucre, Item Shop Rank 1
Earthstone: 250 Lucre, Item Shop Rank 1
Waterstone: 250 Lucre, Item Shop Rank 1
Any Seed x3: 10 Lucre in Bone Fortress, if you really want to buy=20
some
Aroma Oil x4: 250 Lucre apiece, Item Shop Rank 3

Total cost is 1,590.  It will sell for just over 12,000, depending=20
on item type.  (I had just made a knife.)

This recipe isn't really a big deal, it doesn't make as much as the=20
standard Windcap or Pine O'Clock trick, but the nifty thing is that=20
all of these materials can be bought at a store somewhere.

I only know about one established Chocobo diet, and it was written up
by DragonBlood97:

1 level of 1 Cornflower and 2 Dialaurel
18 levels of 2 Cabbadillo and 1 Dialaurel
18 levels of 1 Cabadillo and 2 Bug Meat
25 levels of 1 Pear o' Heels and 2 Cornflower
36 levels of 2 Cabbadillo and 1 Bug Meat

Level 99
    99    99    99    99              DEF:  76/76/76/54
    99    99    99    05              Total: 282 DEF points

Now, I'm not sure if there are others roaming about or not, but this
is the one I use (I'm abysmal at best at making my own diets >_>).

Looks like you'd feed it those three items that many times, in that order.

Example being 4x Dialaurel, Gold Clover, Rocket Papaya. What this says
is you'd feed it those three items 4 times total. And then you go on
to the next one until reach the end.

This is my guess at least.

> 4x Dialaurel, Gold Clover, Rocket Papaya
> 30x Cabbadillo, Gold Clover, Rocket Papaya
> 13x Cabadillo, Dialaurel, Gold Clover
> 51x Cabadillo, Bug Meat, Bug Meat
>

The "4x, 30x" etc. refers to that many levels of the listed foods to=20
feed.  Example, for four levels feed your pet the Dialaurel, Gold=20
Clover, Rocket Papaya, then for 30 levels feed him the Gabbadillo,=20
Gold Clover, Rocket Papaya, then for 13 levels...you get the idea.

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "rei075" <rei075@...> wrote:
>
> I think I understand. Would anyone known how or where, I can get=20
these=20
> products from
>=20
> Dialaurel, Gold Clover, Rocket Papaya, Cabbadillo and Rocket Papaya ?

You can buy Dialaurels and Gold Clovers from the Bone Fortress.  The=20
others you'll have to grow.  Cabbadillos should be simple enough to=20
get, but Rocket Papaya's are exceedingly rare.

See this site (http://www.geocities.com/xo_pitseleh/lom5.html) for=20
some information on growing produce.

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=341658064; y=IZzrG9cyfqqDp1dwsDlRggujcErNNvTKLjiqkSl1xP9k

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, "rei075" <rei075@...> wrote:
>
> What does essence do ?, and what is the maximum figure essence can=20
be=20
> raise to ?
>

Essence, on a weapon, raises attack power. And once it gets to a=20
certain level (2?  I don't know.) it gets that essence's marker,=20
which makes your attacks partly aligned with that essence.  The best=20
way to raise attack power is to first increase a weapon's essence=20
levels.

Essences on armor don't do much (as far as I know) until it gains=20
that essences' marker, which gives you a 10% resistance to attacks=20
of that essence.

Any single essence can usually be raised to 15 using complex forging=20
techniques.  Total, certain essences can hit 15 while others might=20
only get to 14 or 9.  It depends on the material you use.


(This is all off the top of my head, it might be a little off.=20=20
Somebody correct me if i'm off)

not sure of the exact number, but I'm thinking that it's 93, although=20
a quick search showed it could be 97.

In any case, once your HP hits that point you'll regenerate faster=20
than you can be damaged in most scenarios.  Kind of like Pseudo-
Invincibility.

From what I understand, in Nightmare Mode, all enemies are 50 levels stronger; and in No Future Mode, all enemies are at Level 99.

rei075 <rei075@yahoo.co.uk> wrote:                             What is the different between Normal Mode, Nightmare Mode and No Future 
 Mode (I already know each mode is harder as we go on. For example, 
 nightmare mode is more harder then normal mode, and no future is harder

--- In LoM_Kitchen@yahoogroups.com, r_w_7_2 <no_reply@...> wrote:
>
> Just one simple question. Is it possible to temper a weapon to have a=20
> flameburst, freezing or any other status change effect?

I believe you can with the right plunge effects on your weapon. Not
all weapons have them available but some of the plunge attacks are
supposed to cause status effects. You should be able to temper a god
of destruction card onto a sword and get the "flametongue" plunge
attack which causes flameburst. Try looking for a good item tempering
effects chart to see which ones you can use.

--0-665938110-1216292632=:31289
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

There's nothing exactly "special" about it, except that it's fun to play wi=
th friends/family.

You *can* transfer EXP if you want (the game will prompt you to save when t=
he second character leaves), but all Lucre always stays with the first play=
er.

As for that last thing, if the 2P is wearing the ring, then it doesn't do a=
nything. 2Ps don't gain stat benefits from armor. If your 1P is wearing the=
 ring, then yes EXP can be shared between them.

--0-1937700425-1216325040=:33569
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The only thing special about playing 2 players is the second person can bet=
ter control how many xp crystals are picked up by the NPC.=A0 2 player mode=
 isn't done very well in this game.=A0 Not at all like Secret of Mana for s=
nes...=A0 2 player was good in that one. :)

xp gained by the 2nd player stays with the second player, and I don't think=
 forbidden ring can even be equipped on the second player.

Unless you have a friend sitting there bored watching you play the game, or=
 you have already played the game and are getting a friend to play it there=
's no benefit to 2 player mode.

Good Luck,
Ed

p.s. - look at the map placement guide and play through the game following =
one of those setups.=A0 You'll be able to get much better items. :)

Yup, the imported character keeps their stats... but their stats in no way =
effect your own.

Oh, and if their armor has some extra thing on it (like extra lucra/exp/etc=
..), those won't travel over.

 undine =3D=20
0. If you are just starting this weapon then a good start would be:
sala silver
sulpher
sulpher
sulpher
sala silver
glow crystal
sharp claw
3 lilipods
from this point you can keep going on the essence tempering as the plunge a=
ttack will=20
stay on unless you replace it with another.

I forgot to mention that the glow crystal may not be nessecary to get the e=
ssence to 5 but=20
if the last sala silver doesn't work then a glow crystal is a good way to g=
et the job done.=20
Also glow crystals cost 2000 each so it is wasteful to use one if you don't=
 need it since its=20
energy boost wont be enough to get another point. If you are trying to make=
 an =FCber=20
sword out of this it is better to start like normal and just do this when y=
ou first start=20
boosting salamander.  That way you don't waste materials.=20

For those not using a Gameshark, I figured I'd share the method I use to co=
llect coins and grow fruit. I basically just place the Mana Tree between Ho=
me, Mekiv, and the Orchard. I go to the room in Mekiv that has a Land Drago=
n in it, just keep heading to the right and always take the top path. Once =
two spirits show up, choose to not play music and run towards the closer of=
 the two spirits. You should make it in time to get coins.

Shade and Wisp have no effect on Dryad. Only Aura does. The best way to get=
 essecences to 5+, is to start with Shade. I've found that Shade doesn't li=
ke to stick to weapons if you start with any other element. I guess shade d=
oesn't play well with others if it isn't picked first. I've tested this ext=
ensivelly, and found this theory to be true every time I try.=20

From: "tagged_jc" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: The Mana Sword
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=k_CrR8tUoWEGVrukexm6o_-xHkOvoojyih6gTMj5TPIDpM-U
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Actually, Shade and Wisp have a rather direct effect on Dryad.

As long as Wisp > Shade, then Dryad will drain Aura, and Aura can't rise.
As long as Shade > Wisp, then Aura will drain Dryad, and Dryad can't rise.

In addition, if Wisp is present, then Shade can't rise... and if Wisp > Sha=
de, then Wisp will drain Shade to 0.

Both are right! The translated charts are correct for the Japanese version =
of the game. For some reason, before releasing the game in the US, they cha=
nged many material values. Some of these changes make absolutely no sense (=
stones became very light, so make terrible Hammers, whereas cloth now have =
very high Sharp values instead of good technique, so make terrible gloves b=
ut decent spears) but hey, we've got what we've got.

If you're playing the US version, use the charts you'll find here. :)

From: "tagged_jc" <tagged_jc@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: Sulpher/Mercury Problems
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=116656188; y=gshwdxAXsEGbmmp4MwuLvoZUESj-RdHqlNZwL28dYUCsmRqM
X-Yahoo-Profile: tagged_jc

Did you by chance use an All-Items Code to give yourself maximum of every i=
tem? There are a great deal of "dummy" items, that do nothing, and they tak=
e the name from another nearby item. If so, you're probably adding a garbag=
e item that has the name "Mercury" or "Sulpher", but isn't actually the rig=
ht item. In this case, you're adding an item with under 32 energy, and this=
 causes Nymph of Dawn to leave the item (since she is pushed out automatica=
lly in such a case) without actually adding the appropriate wizard card.

Hi, I am playing now and have a dragonscales staff that is 934 attk power. =
 I used an existing recipie on this site plus differing plunge/varnish item=
s.  That was literally the only difference.  I'll look around and see if I =
can point you to it.  the point is, what matters for the entire elemental p=
rocess is not weapon type, but material type.  The only part where weapon t=
ype matters is in plunge/varnish parts. Ah, I found it. look in the file se=
ction for 'dragon uber'.  Just use that and then the appropriate varnish fo=
r staffs.  Mine has three cleric cards.  Should end with 934atk staff

X-Yahoo-Post-EncIP: evtNJ52mU8qd1VkM-av_bwkYFb80LCuBWidDGtc4moPUrzGT
Subject: Re: Chocobo diets
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=77411874; y=x4IqSDeMA3o1a8mcnQQfGwcs7h89cpG51Dh1tyIc6-feyWL2rxk; email=no
X-Yahoo-Profile: geekgirl101

Better late than never...

The 99 in all stats diet is a bad choice for any kind of pet since they can=
 be more of a hinderance than helpful.

For a chocobo fighting with you you'd ideally want one that's aggressive an=
d has got high power and high defenses.  This is a good recipe:

8 cycles of:
    1 =D7 Citrisquid, Citrisquid, Citrisquid
90 cycles of:
    1 =D7 Cabbadillo, Cabbadillo, Dialaurel

Level 99:
Power: 99.0, Skill: 99.0, Defense: 99.0, Magic: 99.0, HP: 99.0, Spirit: 99.=
0, Charm: 12.0, Luck: 5.0
Strike: 94.0, Slash: 94.0, Thrust: 94.0, Magic: 4.0, Total defense: 286
Offense: 59, Lucre: 10,100

The Dialaurel will increase the aggression, so you'll have a pretty powerfu=
l chocobo that will jump right in and attack.

Subject: Re: Polterbox diet ?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=77411874; y=C9kTvJdAWshfqDec4uwqJoynoIUTtzEL8hJacYVHQzKUaNxpfNU; email=no
X-Yahoo-Profile: geekgirl101

Personally I'd ignore that diet.  What it's resulting in is a polterbox whi=
ch has 99 in almost all stats, and it's a very expensive diet.  You don't n=
eed high luck since luck and the polterbox's rare drop increase bonus don't=
 stack.  Since you want to rely on the polterbox's own rare drop increase b=
onus you don't want to make it aggressive or doing high amounts of damage b=
ecause the rare drop increase chance only kicks in when you do the killing =
blow.  Ideally you'd want it to stick like glue to you and do very little o=
f anything else.

Someone came up with this pretty decent recipe:

24 cycles of:
    1 =D7 Cabbadillo, Bug Meat, Squalphin
74 cycles of:
    1 =D7 Cabbadillo, Bug Meat, Bug Meat

Level 99:
Power: 10.0, Skill: 99.0, Defense: 99.0, Magic: 99.0, HP: 99.0, Spirit: 99.=
0, Charm: 3.0, Luck: 29.0
Strike: 50.0, Slash: 99.0, Thrust: 99.0, Magic: 77.0, Total defense: 325
Offense: 59, Lucre: 1,980

This results in a polterbox doing low damage and having no additional trait=
s for attacking.  Since cabbadillos increase both friendly and lonely trait=
s it might end up wandering around but it should stick close to you.  This =
is something I'd have to test myself.

An alternate diet to the previous one is this one:

22 cycles of:
    1 =D7 Cabbadillo, Cabbadillo, Squalphin
1 cycles of:
    1 =D7 Cabbadillo, Squalphin, Gold Clover
75 cycles of:
    1 =D7 Cabbadillo, Bug Meat, Bug Meat

Level 99:
Power: 21.0, Skill: 99.0, Defense: 99.0, Magic: 99.0, HP: 99.0, Spirit: 99.=
0, Charm: 3.0, Luck: 30.0
Strike: 61.0, Slash: 99.0, Thrust: 99.0, Magic: 78.0, Total defense: 337
Offense: 59, Lucre: 1,980

Gives a little more defense and slightly more power, however the additional=
 gold clover will increase friendliness slightly so it should stick around =
more often.

      <p>The database on this group is here: <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"=
_blank" href=3D"https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/LoM_Kitchen/database">h=
ttps://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/LoM_Kitchen/database</a></p><p><br> </p>=
<p>Re: forge calc. I ported it to Java and added utilities like saving/load=
ing recipes, and manipulation of the recipe (like removing something from a=
ny step, reordering...) <a href=3D"http://airelle.info/apps/JForgeW.jar">ht=
tp://airelle.info/apps/JForgeW.jar</a> or <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_bl=
ank" href=3D"http://airelle.info/apps/JForgeW.exe">http://airelle.info/apps=
/JForgeW.exe</a></p><p><br></p><p>Bed of thorns : while tempering, its use =
is to allow multiple world cards, when varnishing, it boosts armor (+50% to=
 all 4 defenses) at the cost of preventing hp regeneration.</p><p><br></p><=
p>Salamander taint : given by sala gold/silver and firestone, and all three=
 add a sala card</p><p><br></p><p>If you want to see all the intricate deta=
ils, you should check the ForgeCode.txt file which is pretty much a straigh=
t rip from the game code. Some of the effects are noted as "special effect =
=3D 1" etc, but with the database, you should be able what it is.<br></p><p=
><br></p><p>Last, while it isn't as active as it used to be, do come on the=
 gamefaqs' board for LoM, you are still more likely to get answers there th=
an here.<br></p><p></p>

    </div>
